story:
In 1967, Rolling Stone magazine founder Jann Wenner asked Baron Wolman to be his first chief photographer, with the agreement that Baron retained ownership of his photographs, while the maga­zine was granted unlimited use of them. Over the next several years Baron gained unprecedented access to some of the greatest artists of the day including The Grateful Dead, The Who, Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd, George Harrison, The Rolling Stones, Joni Mitchell, Eric Clapton, Frank Zappa, and of course, the legendary Jimi Hendrix. On four separate occasions in 1968 and 1970 in San Francisco and New York City, Baron captured Hendrix with "Experience" bass player Noel Redding, and drummer Mitch Mitchell, both on stage during their incendiary performances, and alone in private, intimate settings. For the first time in history, Wolman has opened his coveted Hendrix archive, and with editor/art director Dagon James carefully selected the best shots for full page reproduction. Jimi Hendrix 1968/1970 by Baron Wolman is a new, very limited, collector edition book that marks the 50th anniversary of the first time Baron photographed the Jimi Hendrix Experience at Bill Graham’s Fillmore West in 1968.  

This unique book contains every single frame of film Baron ever shot of The Jimi Hendrix Experience - 422 in total, most of them published here for the first time. In addition to sumptuous full-page reproductions, this book also contains all of Baron's vintage contact sheets, a treasure trove of archival material including Baron's 1968 private photo log book which records his Rolling Stone assignments, and the original tickets and poster designed by Rick Griffin for Hendrix's legendary 4 night, February 1-4, 1968 run of performances in San Francisco, at Bill Graham's Fillmore Auditorium, and Winterland Ballroom. And just when you think that's all, this book goes even deeper by presenting all of Baron's covers and articles about Hendrix from the early days of Rolling Stone magazine with additional archival photographs, new essays, detailed captions, an introduction by legendary music photographer Ross Halfin, and a new interview with Baron. In total, you get over 6,000 words which tell the complete story of Baron's own "Jimi Hendrix Experience." 

This is more than just a book, it's a piece of Rock and Roll history!

Baron's photographs are meticulously reproduced in large format 9 x 11.5" and printed in a 5 color lithographic process with spot varnish, on heavyweight 200gsm matte art paper. The cover, dust jacket, and slipcase are beautifully complimented by metallic silver and purple accents.

We are offering 4 versions of this book which will please any collector. 

The  softcover version which is limited to only 250 copies.

We are also offering a signed and numbered hardcover edition which is limited to 750 copies. Each of these books is hand signed by photographer Baron Wolman and editor/art director Dagon James, and all hard cover copies come with exclusive signed photographs, ephemera and artifacts, all housed in a protective slipcase.  

The 750 hardcover books come in 3 versions. 

1. COLLECTOR EDITION - Books numbered 101-750 are COLLECTOR copies. You get 1(one) 8x10" photo of Hendrix signed by Baron Wolman. The photo alone has a retail value of $300. You will also receive a sheet of 4 postcards by Wolman, and an authorized 5x7" reproduction of the Jimi Hendrix Experience handbill from their 4 night run of performances at San Francisco's Fillmore and Winterland dated February 1-4, 1968.

2. DELUXE EDITION - Books numbered 26-100 are DELUXE copies. You get 2(two) different 8x10" photos of Hendrix signed by Baron Wolman. The 2 photos alone have a retail value of $600. You will also receive a sheet of 4 postcards by Wolman, an authorized 5x7" reproduction of the Jimi Hendrix Experience 1968 handbill, and 1 authentic Jimi Hendrix ticket from one of his 4 performances in San Francisco from February 1-4, 1968. These 50 year old tickets were provided courtesy of the Bill Graham archives.

3. ARCHIVE EDITION - Books numbered 1-25 are ARCHIVE copies. You get 4(four) different 8x10" photos of Hendrix signed by Baron Wolman, 1 photo from each of the 4 occasions Wolman photographed Hendrix. The 4 photos alone have a retail value of $1,200. You will also receive a sheet of 4 postcards by Wolman, an authorized 5x7" reproduction of the Jimi Hendrix Experience 1968 handbill, and 1 authentic Jimi Hendrix ticket from one of his 4 performances in San Francisco from February 1-4, 1968. These 50 year old tickets were provided courtesy of the Bill Graham archives.

Sheet of 4 postcards, and Jimi Hendrix 5x7" reproduction 1968 handbill that come with every hardcover book. Handbill image © Bill Graham Archives.

We are offering 4 different 8 x 10" archival pigment photographs of Jimi Hendrix, all signed by Baron Wolman. The top left photo comes with all 750 hardcover books. The bottom right photo comes with the first 100 copies, and, finally, all four photos come with the first 25 copies! 1 photo from each of the 4 occasions that Wolman photographed Hendrix!

The first 100 copies come with 1 of these authentic Jimi Hendrix tickets from his 4 night run of shows at the Fillmore Auditorium and Winterland Ballroom in San Francisco, February 1-4, 1968. These original tickets were sourced from the Bill Graham Archives. © Bill Graham Archives.

We are enormously proud of how our unique Jimi Hendrix compilation has turned out. If you are not familiar with Baron Wolman's photographs, this book will show you why he is one of the most admired photographers of the 1960's.

Thank you for your support!

story:
My name is Chanan Greenblatt.
After serving in the Israeli army as a photographer, I toyed with the idea of doing something meaningful with my photographs, which captured unique situations in the daily lives of combat unit soldiers.

My photographs manage to capture miniscule moments in time. They symbolize the essence of small and big moments in the lives of combat soldiers in the Israeli army.
I believe that the creativity of art has the potential to create poignant discussions around issues regrading the effects of traumatic events that soldiers like these must deal with.

This inspired me to contact THE ISRAEL CENTER FOR THE TREATMENT OF PSYCHOTRAUMA.
The center runs a truly inspiring program for soldiers who formerly served in combat units, giving them the necessary tools to cope with and integrate traumatic experiences.



My photographs bring home the reality of what soldiers face, and in doing so, can help raise awareness about the importance of providing post trauma services. 
The gates are then opened for the center to raise more funds.
The program is entirely donor supported and is therefore in need of funding in order to expand and continue this important work.

The goal is to have an exhibition of my photographs, which will be for sale to the general public. The funds raised will be dedicated to THE ISRAEL CENTER FOR THE TREATMENT OF PSYCHOTRAUMA.

The opening exhibition will display 35 photographs for sale in limited numbers. Initilly, it will be open to a select audience and will be well covered in the Israeli media.  Thereafter, we will launch a second exhibition which will be open to the public at large.


 

 

The Israel Center for the Treatment of Psychotrauma (ICTP), is a world renowned organization in the trauma field. The Center, affiliated with the Herzog Hospital in Jerusalem, and the Hebrew university, runs many different trauma treatment programs and is also teaching in the field of trauma and resilience.
ICTP has developed a unique program for groups of discharged combat IDF soldiers called 'Peace of Mind' (POM). POM paves the way back to civilian life for young men and women who have served 3 or more years in high-risk combat units in the IDF. The program identifies units who have faced exposure to extremely difficult combat situations and provides the necessary treatment which aids in strengthening their emotional health and resilience.

The program's goal is to ease the integration of those men and women back to civilian life following their three or more years of dedicated service and allow them to embark upon a healthy and productive civilian life. This is done by allowing the veterans an opportunity to talk about what they've been through, and provide them with tools to deal with their combat related experiences.
 
The participating combat teams go through a minimum "cooling" period of one year following their release from active service and prior to entering the POM program. The program takes place over a 90 day period and is led by two experienced mental health professionals. The program includes two workshops in Israel (opening and closing seminars), as well as a week's trip abroad, which is the centerpiece of the program.

The therapy sessions provide the group with the opportunity to shake off a long service period, lay aside their rifle and helmet, and talk about how they feel in this whirlpool that is their life.

LINK to the main site of The Israel Center for the Treatment of Psychotrauma:
http://www.traumaweb.org/

 

We want to thank you sincerely for taking the time to read about us and for making a donation.


We intend to raise enough money to fund an inaugural opening exhibition in a number of different locations in Israel.
The first night is planned to take place in a beautiful loft named "URBAINCA" based in the city of Tel Aviv. 
Here are some pictures we took of the actual place for you to see:



Our goal is to to plan future exhibitions overseas. Perhaps even in YOUR own home town!

The exhibition will also incorporate workshops dealing with post trauma and public awareness regarding this sensitive topic.

Art work and tickets to the exhibition are limited.



In addition to the photographs that will be issued in full scale size at the exhibitions, we also intend to publish a book containing texts and an entire range of photographs. Your donations will help cover the costs of design and print.



It is crucial for us to reach the international crowd.

The website will offer an online store so donors may purchase art work and copies of "Portraits Of Combat" official book.

The website will also post various activities, updates and our collective progress.

All the money raised by selling my art will go to THE ISRAEL CENTER FOR THE TREATMENT OF PSYCHOTRAUMA and their amazing project.

With appreciation and humble gratitude,

Chanan Greenblatt (photographer)
Naor Lev  (video art) 
Ran Menachem  (video editing)

story:
Our Story

My name is Dino Mangano, and I am a high school teacher, as well as a freelance photographer!  One of my passions, in addition to photography, is wine, specifically Michigan wine.  Most of America know about the West Coast wineries, but very few know about the amazing wines made here on the "North Coast".  My dream is to create a Michigan Wineries Photo Book that is as vibrant, unique, and appealing as the wineries and vineyards it will contain.


The Impact

Not only will this book be a wonderful collectors item, but it will help to open the eyes of American wine lovers to the special wines created here in Michigan, a State that is in dire need of positive economic growth.


What We Need & What You Get

This plan will not be overly expensive, but any endeavor like this is just out of my tight budget at this time.  I will need to take a 3-4 day photo excursion to the Leelaneau and Old Mission Peninsulas, during August or September.  I'll need funding to cover basic trip costs (lodging, food, gas, etc).  Once done, I'll need limited funds for editing, printing and publishing.  My goal is to do all this for $1000.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word!  This project can help not only a blossoming photographer, but also lend a helping hand to a wonderful area of a wonderful State.

story:
Hello,

My name is Victoria Cagol, I am an italian Photography and Film student at the Edinburgh Napier University in Scotland, about to graduate.

Let me introduce you to a project that has been on my mind for years, I had to wait for the right time to start working on it and now I need your help to finish it.

A few lines on the Death Marches

This term was acquired during World War II to describe “the forcible movements of prisoners in critical conditions by Nazi Germany”.

The town of Oswiecim in Poland is better known worldwide by its german name, Auschwitz, and for its dark past.

When in January 1945 the Red Army began advancing and conquering land in Poland, the german government gave the order to leave the concentration camps in the area and destroy the evidence of mass killings. Even though they were losing land, this was not seen as the imminent lost of the war, but as a temporary obstacle towards a certain result. This implied a continuous need for labour force, meaning the camps had to be emptied and their occupants moved to new locations in safe territory, where they could still work in the country’s war factories.

January 18th,1945 marks the day when prisoners began their march from Auschwitz. It is estimated that more than 60.000 cadaverous prisoners were forced to walk through critical weather conditions. Countless died and the survivors were crammed on trains toward new camps, such as Dachau, Dora- Mittelbau, Bergen-Belsen.

The project

My project focus is the evacuation of Auschwitz-Birkenau camp towards the city of Wodzisław Śląski (or Loslau in german) approximately 70 km away. (Blue and Red route).

As the map shows, through the researches of the last months, I have retraced the route of the march and found the locations where its victims were buried, along with several monuments and tablets in their commemoration. 

Through photography I will follow and document the route and the places of remembrance scattered along the way. Testimonies shared with me by survivors of the march and Auschwitz concentration camps will be added to the final work.

The work will then be exhibited in Edinburgh and London in June 2014 and hopefully in many other occasions.

Why am I doing this

I have always had a strong determination in doing my part to keep the memory of the Holocaust alive and to help people know the true events of those terrible dark years. I believe that it is only when we know our history and the reasons that lead to certain events in our past, that we can then move forward to a brighter future.

Another strong reason that brings me to the realization of this project is the personal need to pay respect to the countless lost lives of the Holocaust. I believe collecting their testimonies and developing this work will be a concrete way to do so.

Why I need your help

I will be traveling to Poland on more than one occasion over the next months:

My first visit was on the 17th of January till the first week of February. For which I was able to cover the expenses personally.

Your contribution will help me finance a second longer visit for the months of April and possibly May which I will not be able to support otherwise.

This visit will focus on taking photographs of the areas I was not able to cover in January, while re-shooting where needed. While in Oswiecim I will have the possibility to continue my researches at the Auschwitz Museum's library, while possibly meeting with survivors I have got in contact with in the past months.

Also, I will be able to follow the light blue and the yellow route shown on the previous map.

The "light blue" route shows another march from Auschwitz concentration camps. Part of the prisoners ended their march in Gliwice where they were pushed on trains, others continued and reached Raszczyce where they were sent to Gross-Rosen Concentration Camp.

This project will be exhibited in Edinburgh and London in June 2014. If the money raised passes the funding goal, it will be used to cover the printing and framing expenses for these two occasions.


Anything helps and I thank you from the bottom of my heart for your help. If you want to support this project, but can not afford to invest money in it, it will still be of great help if you could share this page with your friends, by email or on Facebook or any other social network.

Thank you!



To get in contact with me: victoria.cagol@hotmail.com

To see the ongoing project website:
www.deathmarches1945.com

To see some of my past photographic work and know more about me: www.victoriacagolphotography.com
story_txt: Hello, My name is Victoria Cagol, I am an italian Photography and Film student at the Edinburgh Napier University in Scotland, about to graduate.Let me introduce you to a project that has been on my mind for years, I had to wait for the right time to start working on it and now I need your help to finish it.A few lines on the Death MarchesThis term was acquired during World War II to describe “the forcible movements of prisoners in critical conditions by Nazi Germany”.The town of Oswiecim in Poland is better known worldwide by its german name, Auschwitz, and for its dark past.When in January 1945 the Red Army began advancing and conquering land in Poland, the german government gave the order to leave the concentration camps in the area and destroy the evidence of mass killings. Even though they were losing land, this was not seen as the imminent lost of the war, but as a temporary obstacle towards a certain result. This implied a continuous need for labour force, meaning the camps had to be emptied and their occupants moved to new locations in safe territory, where they could still work in the country’s war factories.January 18th,1945 marks the day when prisoners began their march from Auschwitz. It is estimated that more than 60.000 cadaverous prisoners were forced to walk through critical weather conditions. Countless died and the survivors were crammed on trains toward new camps, such as Dachau, Dora- Mittelbau, Bergen-Belsen. The projectMy project focus is the evacuation of Auschwitz-Birkenau camp towards the city of Wodzisław Śląski (or Loslau in german) approximately 70 km away. (Blue and Red route). As the map shows, through the researches of the last months, I have retraced the route of the march and found the locations where its victims were buried, along with several monuments and tablets in their commemoration. Through photography I will follow and document the route and the places of remembrance scattered along the way. Testimonies shared with me by survivors of the march and Auschwitz concentration camps will be added to the final work. The work will then be exhibited in Edinburgh and London in June 2014 and hopefully in many other occasions.Why am I doing thisI have always had a strong determination in doing my part to keep the memory of the Holocaust alive and to help people know the true events of those terrible dark years. I believe that it is only when we know our history and the reasons that lead to certain events in our past, that we can then move forward to a brighter future. Another strong reason that brings me to the realization of this project is the personal need to pay respect to the countless lost lives of the Holocaust. I believe collecting their testimonies and developing this work will be a concrete way to do so.Why I need your helpI will be traveling to Poland on more than one occasion over the next months:My first visit was on the 17th of January till the first week of February. For which I was able to cover the expenses personally.Your contribution will help me finance a second longer visit for the months of April and possibly May which I will not be able to support otherwise. This visit will focus on taking photographs of the areas I was not able to cover in January, while re-shooting where needed. While in Oswiecim I will have the possibility to continue my researches at the Auschwitz Museum's library, while possibly meeting with survivors I have got in contact with in the past months.Also, I will be able to follow the light blue and the yellow route shown on the previous map. The "light blue" route shows another march from Auschwitz concentration camps. Part of the prisoners ended their march in Gliwice where they were pushed on trains, others continued and reached Raszczyce where they were sent to Gross-Rosen Concentration Camp.This project will be exhibited in Edinburgh and London in June 2014. If the money raised passes the funding goal, it will be used to cover the printing and framing expenses for these two occasions.Anything helps and I thank you from the bottom of my heart for your help. If you want to support this project, but can not afford to invest money in it, it will still be of great help if you could share this page with your friends, by email or on Facebook or any other social network.Thank you!To get in contact with me: victoria.cagol@hotmail.comTo see the ongoing project website: www.deathmarches1945.comTo see some of my past photographic work and know more about me: www.victoriacagolphotography.com

story:
VERSION FRANÇAISE ET CONTREPARTIES CI-DESSOUS

In 2015, when a refugee camp settled in the Maximilian Park in the center of Brussels, we decided to work together around a photographic project on the issue of asylum and the reception given to it in our country.

The starting point was therefore the improvisation of this refugee camp, and its dismantling a few months later, when the commune shot down all the trees for the official cause of "age-wasting".

We went to one of the many centers run by Fedasil (the Federal Agency for the Reception of Asylum Seekers), and we got permission to enter and meet these people waiting for a response from the General Commissariat for Refugees and Stateless Persons (CGRA).

At the Maximilian Park, then in this reception center, we first used a documentary approach. We took pictures, without prior aesthetic decision, welcoming all we could see in the meetings that we made.

In a second step, we created, in this reception center, various spaces of workshops, over a period of three years. The first type of workshop revolved around the portrait. We photographed the people, printed the portrait directly, then we proposed to each to intervene on his image.

We also proposed workshops around images representing places of life: they were able to redraw the outlines, transform them, color them.

 

In this device, we then use a photocopier to make another type of portrait. We wanted to talk about the asylum procedure itself, its heavy administrative burden. Hence the idea of ​​subverting a bureaucracy tool. The use of this administrative tool refers to the question of waiting for a response from the state. This letter will decide the fate of these people in transit: a "positive" or "negative" to their asylum application.

 

It was for us to create a space, a device that allows collaboration in the construction of images. We consider that every image is a construction, and not a faithful reproduction of "reality". Our approach is integrative, setting up workshops, joint creation actions, trying to collaborate to the maximum with those who agree to be photographed.

The idea of ​​making a book appeared very quickly as a matter of course : to create an object that could contain all these productions, and that could pay tribute to those people who gave us their time.

In order for this book to come into being, we needed a publisher. It is Art Paper Editions (APE) who has given us its trust, and we are very happy!

Now, we need money. That is why we are asking for your participation today: you can pre-buy the book, or support the project thanks to the various counterparts! You can also help us by sharing and talking about the project around you.

Funds raised will be used for printing and creating the book. If our goal were to be exceeded, the extra money would be used to create an exhibition. Thanks!

 

The Photobook: 

Size: 17 X 24 cm

Cover:  open spine paperback with dust jacket (inside dust jacket PMS gold)

Paper: coated and uncoated paper, Munken Lynx, Woodstock coloured paper

Print: offset

Pages: 144

Texts: Julián Barón & Nicolas Prignot

 

FRANÇAIS

 

En 2015, lorsqu’un camp de réfugiés s’est installé dans le parc Maximilien au centre de Bruxelles, nous avons décidé de travailler ensemble autour d’un projet photographique, sur la question de l’asile et de l’accueil qui lui est fait dans notre pays.

Le point de départ a donc été l’improvisation de ce camp de réfugiés, et son démantèlement quelques mois plus tard, où la commune a abattu tous les arbres pour cause officielle de « dépérissement dû à l’âge ».

Nous nous sommes rendus dans l’un des nombreux centres gérés par Fedasil (l’Agence fédérale pour l’accueil des demandeurs d’asile), et nous avons obtenu l’autorisation d’entrer et de rencontrer ces personnes en attente d’une réponse du Commissariat Général aux Réfugiés et aux Apatrides (CGRA).

Au parc Maximilien, puis dans ce centre d’accueil, nous avons d’abord utilisé une approche documentaire. Nous avons pris des images, sans décision préalable quant à l’esthétique, accueillant tout ce que nous pouvions voir au gré des rencontres que nous avons faites.

Dans un second temps, nous avons créé, dans ce centre d’accueil, différents espaces d’ateliers, sur une période de trois ans. Le premier type d’atelier tournait autour du portrait. Nous avons photographié les personnes, imprimé directement leurs portraits, puis nous avons proposé à chacun d’intervenir sur son image.

Nous avons aussi proposé des ateliers autour d’images représentant les lieux de vie : ils ont pu en redessiner les contours, les transformer, les colorier.

 

Dans ce dispositif, nous avons ensuite utilisé une photocopieuse pour réaliser un autre type de portrait. Nous souhaitions parler de la procédure de demande d’asile en elle-même, de sa lourdeur administrative. D’où l’idée de subvertir un outil de la bureaucratie. L’utilisation de cet outil administratif renvoie à la question de l’attente d’une réponse de l’Etat. Ce courrier qui décidera en effet du sort de ces personnes en transit : un « positif » ou un « négatif » à leur demande d’asile.

Il s’agissait pour nous de créer un espace, un dispositif qui permette une collaboration dans la construction des images. Nous considérons que toute image est une construction, et non une reproduction fidèle de la « réalité ». Notre démarche se veut intégrative, mettant en place des ateliers, des actions de création commune, tentant de collaborer au maximum avec ceux qui acceptent de se laisser photographier.

L’idée de faire un livre est apparue très vite comme une évidence : créer un objet qui puisse contenir toutes ces productions, et qui puisse rendre hommage à ces personnes qui nous ont accordé leur temps.

Pour que ce livre puisse voir le jour, il nous fallait avant tout un éditeur. C'est Art Paper Editions (APE) qui nous a accordé sa confiance, et nous en sommes très heureux !

Maintenant, nous avons besoin d’argent. C’est pourquoi nous sollicitons aujourd’hui votre participation : vous pouvez pré-acheter le livre, ou soutenir le projet grâce aux différentes contreparties ! Vous pouvez aussi nous aider en partageant et en parlant du projet autour de vous. 

Les fonds récoltés serviront à l’impression et à la création du livre. Si notre objectif devait être dépassé, l’argent supplémentaire servirait à créer une exposition. Merci !

 

Le livre: 

Taille: 17 X 24 cm

Couverture:  souple, dos ouvert avec jaquette (intérieur PMS gold)

Papier: coated et uncoated, Munken Lynx, Woodstock coloured paper

Technique d'impression: offset

Pages: 144

Textes: Nicolas Prignot & Julián Barón

 

Les contreparties:

 

*Pour 40 €, une de ces deux images sera glissée dans le livre (Surprise !) :

 

*Pour 100€, en plus du livre signé, vous pouvez choisir une parmi ces trois images, tirage Fine Art Mat, A3 :

 

*Pour 150 €, en plus du livre signé, vous pouvez choisir une parmi ces trois images, tirage Fine Art Mat A3 :

 

*Pour 200€, en plus du livre signé, vous pouvez choisir un de ces 2 diptyques, tirage Fine Art Mat A3 : 

 

*Pour 250€, en plus du livre signé, vous pouvez choisir une de ces deux images, tirage Fine Art Mat, format 40x60cm : 

*Pour 250€, en plus du livre signé, vous pouvez choisir cette image, tirage Fine Art Mat, Format 40x60cm :

 

*Pour 500€, en plus du livre signé, vous pouvez choisir parmi ces 5 images, tirage Fine Art Mat, format 40x60cm, contrecollé sur aluminium Dibond :

story:
The time has come. . .

  For me to finally make a more serious stab at professional photography.  I'm a 32 year old chemist looking to branch out from my lab job and pursue what I consider one of the best of my artistic talents as a career - photography.  I'm already working, but there is only so much I can do with the gear I have.  Now that I am starting to collect some impressive glass, it's time for a full frame body!

 

The Goal. . . 

  A Canon 6d with 24-105mm f4 L lens.  Retails for $2899.00.  With tax, that amounts to $3138.17.  The extra is to cover fees.  The reason for going in on the kit instead of just the body is because all my zoom lenses are for APS-C bodies.  Most of my work is done with fast primes, but there are times when you just can't carry all of them along.  

 

  Should the unspeakable happen and I don't reach my goal, the funds will go towards buying the body only.  And should I not get enough even for that, then I will ask everyone I know for cash for my birthday and try to make up the difference that way.  Point being, I will make this happen.

 

  Should I go over my goal, never fear that I shall spend the excess on strippers and whiskey - there are far too many accessories, lenses, flashes, tripods, etc. for me to ever collect them all.  But I would definitely start with a bag to put it in.  And should I get enough, a 5d mkIII would be a more than suitable replacement. . . .

 

What this means to the world at large. . .

  Well, lots of great creative common license photos for one.  Happier clients with better photos for another.  It means I don't have to be 20 feet away to take advantage of my best lenses.  It also means plenty of multiangle videos of events, fire dancing, effigy burns - all of which I tend to releaes under CC:A licenses.  More than anything, with a better camera, I get to create, document, and share better art.

  Also, there are some great perks for the people who contribute, like half-day shoots with prints for less money than I would typically charge for a shoot that long, or discounts for prints from my smugmug account.  Unfortunately, you need to live in Texas to take advantage of some of these, unless you're so in love with my work that you feel the need to pay for my travel (which would be amazing and flattering).

story:
What is PIXXERS?

Pixxers is the first mobile platform for crowdsourcing photos via a global community. Pixxers offers a really disruptive solution:

STOP SEARCHING. START WISHING!

Need a Photo?

With Pixxers you don’t have to browse through thousands of stockphotos any longer to find the right picture. Simply ask the global community to shoot exactly the photo you need! 

Make a wish!

Wishing for a photo is really easy: Place your wish via the Pixxers App and with the help of all the pixxers around the world you will get exactly what you want: taylor-made, genuine photos! Just pick the one you like most.

FULFILL THE WISHES OF OTHER PIXXERS

Take a picture.

Via PIXXERS you will receive the wishes of other PIXXERS users. And with a little luck, you are in the right place at the right time to shoot the perfect picture! Or upload pictures you shot - with any photo app - from your library.

Earn money.

If a wish is private you can use the photos you get for free. If you receive a commercial wish, you can earn money, regardless if you are an amateur or a professional photographer. Will you shoot the best picture? Will you get the money? It's up to you!

PIXXERS is fun... and social!

To put it very simple: Mankind has always been devided into hunters and collectors. PIXXERS is one modern instrument based on these very archetypical facts. So if you receive a wish, the hunter in you gets alive! On the other side we all are social beings: If it's not too difficult we really like to fulfill others wishes! To make it even more social you can use Facebook and Twitter to share your activities on PIXXERS with your friends!

How can you support us? 

Support us by funding and get rewarded with plenty of interesting perks: higher ranking (= means higher prices for your photos), better conditions (to save money if you buy pictures), our iconic PIXXERS T-shirts and some great other things...

Support us by using PIXXERS: Download the new PIXXERS app for free - for iPhone or Android, try it out, play around, fool around and have fun. 

Support us by word of mouth: If you like PIXXERS tell your friends and share it over your networks!

Support us by co-creating: Tell us what we could do better. Tell us new ideas to use PIXXERS. And if you find bugs or things we could do better, just let us know! 

What we will do with your help:

Our next steps are essential to refine PIXXERS and make it a perfect global marketplace for photos: We will

  • Power up  PIXXERS with additional features
  • Offer webinars to show people how to use PIXXERS best for special use cases
  • Implement a ranking system
  • Set up and refine the fully functional PIXXERS web application
  • Test & refine the commercial features
  • Integrate more features for professional photographers
  • Set up a global payment system
  • Refine our matching engine

Donate, share & get 5 friends to do the same!

Set up a global payment system
Refine our matching engine

Donate, share & get 5 friends to do the same!

story:
Please know ... I am not looking for donations or charity. Your receiving your perks i.e. photographic prints, photography courses and limited release prints is very important to me. 

Our retail value of the perk is more than the contribution asked/attached to the perk.

Thank you for looking at the Remember Forever story.

 

The story so far ...

My name is Luke Ballard. Five years ago I began Remember Forever Photography in Australia. It started with me selling photographs and prints at a market stall, grew into a portrait studio and is now about teaching photography and sharing my passion for photography with everyone I meet.

The video above is my voice. It is a summary of what we do in Australia and this is a trial promotional video we are currently using on our website. To me, it sums up our product philosophy, our core beliefs and our aims in the marketplace.

It's not a great video but it is the easiest way to show you our product.

The philosophy behind Remember Forever is that everyone and anyone can learn how to take amazing photographs - and in this day and age, capturing that special moment is important - hence our brand name of Remember Forever.

This week my wife was offered a transfer with her company to New York - forced to face one of those career choices where it is her work or her husband we've decided to try for both. 

For the last five years I have slowly built Remember Forever up and sacrificed a lot in doing so. We don't own a home (we currently live with Nicole's parents), there are weeks that Remember Forever's staff wages have had to be paid out of Nicole's salary and savings. It has been a lot of hard work to follow my passion for sharing photography with everyone.

At times it has felt like a hobby project rather than a viable business.

It might have been simpler if I was turned on by money and was happy to sell myself to the highest bidder - but each day I feel rewarded being able to share my love of photography as my career.

The good news is, for the first time in five years there is light at the end of the tunnel. After a lot of work and sacrifices, Remember Forever is almost at the point of hitting the big leagues. Then out of thin air my wife is offered the transfer of a lifetime to New York. I can't ask her to turn it down - it wouldn't be fair. At the same time, the only way I can come to New York and start Remember Forever there without support from the IndieGoGo community is to pull apart everything we've worked for in Australia, lose everything we've built and start over.

However, I feel with the support of the IndieGoGo community it is possible we can keep Australia operating and open a Remember Forever in New York, so I can follow my wife to the United States.

This campaign is to finance the opening, licencing, marketing, insuring and staffing a New York studio and school for beginner to intermediate photography students. The goal is to do so in such a way that the Australian Remember Forever has a chance of continuing operation under a new Manager.

The physical benefits to me of the campaign are the continued operation of my business in Australia and the expansion of my business to the greatest city in the world and the emotional benefits are that I can join my wife in the U.S. while she pursues her career.

I have loved photography for over 20 years and am devoted to sharing that love and passion for photography with everyone who attends one of our classes in Australia. If you look at our website or our Facebook page you will see the hundreds of customer testimonials and student feedback from attending and participating in our courses.

I am devoted to bringing this same quality of photographic education and service to New York. Our systems and educational modules have been refined over several years and every customer we've had loves us. We are also amongst the most affordable with classes and courses costing on average less than $100. We've focused more on sharing our love of photography than charging an arm or a leg to do so.

If you look at our website: www.rememberforever.com.au you will see who we are, what we do and how we do it.  If you visit our Facebook page: www.facebook.com/rememberforeverphotography you will see the people who we've taught, the customers whose moments we've photographed and the feedback from everyone we encounter.

If you met my wife, you'd understand why I'm not letting her go to New York without me :)

What We Need & Where It Goes:

There is no limit on where we could use funds in opening a New York school - the more we could raise then the larger our studio space (and better neighborhood) it could be in. 

Our core goal is $40,000 which will allow us to do the following:

  • Finance relocation and L2 visa expenses for myself (Nicole's are paid for by her company).
  • Lease small office & studio space
  • Obtain licencing and permits required by City and State of New York and the Department of Labour
  • Market and advertise Remember Forever in the New York area
  • Purchase and obtain equipment (computers, cameras & lighting)
  • Hire two student/graduating photographers in New York to train in Remember Forever style, systems and educational modules
  • Insurance costs of the business & medical insurance for staff
  • Make a difference to beginning photographers in New York

If we don't hit $40,000 then we use whatever funding we do receive prioritizing:

  1. Relocation and Visa costs       ($  8,500 total)
  2. Licences, Permits, Insurance   ($  6,000 total)
  3. Equipment Purchase              ($  8,000 total)
  4. Marketing                           (Bottomless Pit)

This would leave office and studio space as well as staff hiring a lower priority financially. 

No matter what I am following my wife, delivering the perks and opening this school (even if it is outdoors in the middle of Winter). I am equally as passionate about my wife as I am photography and I mean to have them both.

If we were to exceed our target then the studio/class space could be bigger and better. We could hire more staff and run outreach programs teaching underprivileged kids about photography - and perhaps lead them to the career that has made me so happy.

By hiring more staff we would be able to run classes more frequently. Remember Forever Australia currently offer 15 standard workshops and courses, a variety of Masterclasses and also extended programs for high school students and adult photographers alike. 

New York will start with five different courses initially and expand outwards from there based on the number of staff we could hire.

 

What this could mean ...

This campaign isn't about asking people to finance me doing what I love doing. It isn't about giving a successful business more money to grow.

We are successful in that we survived the global economic crisis. We aren't yet successful in terms of profit and size, though we hope one day to be. For us, our size is measured in potential.

This campaign is about financing two things:

  1. Sharing a love of photography with every New Yorker who owns a camera
  2. Allowing my wife and I to live on the same continent and both do what we love

The visa the Immigration Attorneys are having me enter on is an L2 visa.

Rather than coming to the States on the visa and taking a job that pays a lot of money, could go to someone else and I might not appreciate, I'd rather create an industry. I'm not wanting to take someones job - I want to share my love of photography and hire New Yorkers who share that love.

I could make a lot of money as a fashion or travel photographer (and used to) but over the last five years have grown to love what Remember Forever stands for - that anyone can learn how to use their camera and take amazing photographs.

One of the biggest complements I have ever received from a class I've run was "I learned more in three hours with Luke than I did in six weeks full time at an Arts College studying Photography."

I also love being near my wife and spending time traveling away from her on assignment is difficult - we haven't even been married two years yet. Her contract in New York is for longer than we've been married :(

As I said at the beginning, I began Remember Forever with nothing but my camera. I started selling photographic prints at market stalls on weekends and visiting customers homes to photograph them of an evening every day during the week. Eventually I earned enough for my studio in Brisbane. I ran our first workshop "People, Children and Your Family" as a birthday party for a friend - it is now amongst our most popular courses.

Unfortunately through the Global Economic Crisis and the rising costs of overheads, the studio had to close down and we almost lost the business. We carried on though with the belief that one day it would work, that somehow everything would come together.

Over five years I have built Remember Forever to be a trusted and respected brand in Australia. We are growing every week and one day soon Australia's Remember Forever team will be profitable rather than scraping by every week.

I know that coming to New York to start again in a new and more expensive marketplace is risky. Some may call it stupid. :)

I am excited about the challenge of starting again in New York but realistic at the same time. When I started in Australia, it was my own country and we had a support network of friends and family. I know opening New York is going to be harder but I am determined to succeed. 

Funding means that I can start with what we're great at - the courses and classes and hire good local people to help build the brand locally.

It means that in December we can start setting up and fulfilling our perks. In January we can open with photography classes in New York City. It means we are hiring New Yorkers and training them to grow and run a photography business. It means my wife and I are on the same continent.

The perks for helping are beautiful photos captured with my first love of New York in full bloom. Perks also include some of our classes and tours pre-purchased and then we have also included some luxury items - limited editions and one offs.

I have outlined these over in the Perks section. More importantly, you'll be a part of the Remember Forever community. Our survival so far in Australia is due to our customers. A group that with us have become so passionate about photography that life for them is now about capturing those special moments.

The opportunity that New York has over Australia is you won't just be capturing moments, you now have an opportunity to help create them.

I will be exploring New York on my arrival and taking the first series of photographs that will be used in our courses and classes - these will become limited edition prints for perks also.

All perks (whether vouchers, prints or books) will be delivered in time for Christmas.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand not everyone can assist with funding. In fact, if everyone could help with funding I would strongly suspect the community of money laundering.

If you look at this and think that it's not for you to fund, that this isn't an exciting prospect for you then don't feel bad. I do understand.

I would ask you to please consider that it may be for someone else and share it with your social networks. Tweet it, Facebook it, Share it, Post it. If you know someone and they own a camera or have any precious moments in their life, then we're a company that may be something they are interested in.

If you know someone who loves photography, heck, even someone who owns a camera in the New York area then point them this way.

If you are close personal friends with Donald Trump (or even Don Jr.) then please let them know about us - point them this way :)

story:
From research project to awareness through photos

As a freelance journalist and photographer I accompanied Mouna Chambon, a French researcher to Vanuatu last year to document the impact of climate change in the region. We visited three main islands of the Vanuatu archipelago; Nguna, Espiritu Santo and Tanna. On each island we stayed with families within local communities and interviewed them while participating in their everyday life. Each island is faced with a different situation, whether it be water scarcity, food shortage, or an increase in natural disasters. These varying scenarios all impact negatively on the everyday life of the islanders, and they can also be seen in other vulnerable nations around the world, not just Vanuatu.

We also found women are significantly more vulnerable than men in Vanuatu, as most commonly it is the woman’s responsibility to gather food and collect water. Domestic violence and gender inequality is at a high level, particularly on the island of Tanna. When dealing with climate change in these regions the major solution is adaptation strategies. If women, who are closer to the affects of climate change, do not have any political representation, whether it be at public or national level, then this makes it difficult to come up with solutions for the community to pull through these adverse affects.

Impact of the photo book ‘Facing Climate Change in Vanuatu’

This photo book illustrates all these issues through visual story telling and aims to increase awareness that climate change is real and now. It is hoped that through the publishing of this book people in more developed nations may see in a more tangible way the impact of mass consumption and disregard for the environment and atmosphere. Also, with increased awareness more NGOs also see the viability in helping regions.

Details of the photo book project

If successful, this crowdfunding campaign will enable 100 photo books to be published, as an initial run. Many of you will claim them through ‘perks’ of donating, though the rest will be available in June. During this month, and launching on the same day as World Oceans Day on the 8th of June, a photography exhibition of around 30 select photos will be displayed at La Recyclerie in Paris, France. This can be seen as the official launch of this awareness campaign and also the photo book. All of the photos exhibited are published in the book plus extras to help tell the story.

A French fund called Cap sur le Monde has granted the money to produce the exhibition, now the money just needs to be raised privately for the publishing of the photo book. That’s where you come in.

As mentioned, the initial number of books printed will be 100. Each book is 46 pages, 8 x 10 inches/ 20x25 cm, 148 gsm premium matte, full colour paper with a soft cover. There are 48 photos within the book and it is written in both French and English.

Help make this a reality by purchasing a campaign perk

If you can help with donations to make this publishing a reality it would be greatly appreciated. If we do not raise the amount asked for in this campaign we will be unable to print 100 books and instead will only be able to print the number of books preordered through perks claimed. There are various visual perks you can purchase for yourself, or better still, a friend. Please do share the campaign to your community and continue to spread the awareness of the impact of climate change.

For the latest project updates please join my media page on Facebook or Twitter. If you require any further information please email info@tessafox.com

story:
This is a story about Ilona

(Ilona)

Ilona is a 23 year-old student from Slovenia. She travelled from her small hometown of Kamnik to a far away city of Rotterdam in Netherlands. All for following her dream of becoming a professional photographer. 

It was hard in the beginning, being far away from her family and friends, far away from the beautiful nature of Slovenia, in a country that speaks a language that she couldn't understand. But I guess every beginning is hard. 

She successfully finished the 1st year at the Academy of Willem de Kooning.  Studying made Ilona super happy as she noticed that her skills and understanding of Photography were improving a lot trough the year. It gave her so much motivation and during her summer vacation Ilona was working very hard, without any free days, saving up all the money to buy herself a new, better camera.

(Ilona's photo - You can check more of her work here:  https://www.facebook.com/eyeloneah/ , https://eyeloneah.com/ )

After going back to school she decided to sell her old camera together with all the equipment  that she had and combined with her savings it would be just enough to buy a better one. She posted an add on a online page and soon she got a call from a stranger, saying that he want's to buy all the  equipment. The stranger came to visit Ilona at her apartment and asked her all about the camera, equipment and even for advice on how to take better pictures. After some tea and all these questions the stranger made her the transfer (of 1500€) to her account via mobile phone. Ilona, being a little bit naive, but mostly just trustful gave him all the  equipment and he left. But she never got the money on her account...

(Ilona's photo - You can check more of her work here:  https://www.facebook.com/eyeloneah/ , https://eyeloneah.com/ )

So this very much uncompassionate act left young Ilona studying photography in Netherlands without a camera and without the resources to buy a new one.

After hearing her story we were all very angry but mostly just sad, not being able to comprehend the fact how anyone would do such a thing to a young student, without a job, at the beginning of her path.

As we really wanted to help her, but not being able to give her any money, we were all trying to find another way. The idea that came to mind was; why not invest our time and skills into a project that would help us raise some money from kind-hearted people all over the world.

And project Ilona was born :)

What We Need & What You Get

Our basic goal is 1500 € (1700$), which was the amount Ilona was supposed to get by selling her equipment. This is the minimum amount she would need to buy a camera, that would be more appropriate for her skill level, than the one she had before.

Of course any amount is still very helpful, so no matter how much we raise, it all goes into the camera fund! :) 

Because we are really thankful for any support that we get, everyone who donates can choose to receive a unique, handmade gift which we will pack and send to you by post.

How it works;

We created a few products into which we put a lot of time and love. When you donate a certain amount you can choose to receive a small gift as a token of our gratitude. All these gifts are handmade in Slovenia.

If you donate:

*Any amount, you get:  1x certificate for being an awesome person (.PDF)

*12$, you get:   1x handmade wooden camera key chain

*22$, you get:   1x hand printed T-shirt

*45$ you get:   1x handmade wooden camera SD card holder                                     

Of course you can choose to donate without taking the gifts. :)

This project is running until 15th of December. After the project finishes, we will pack and send you the goods to the address that you give us. As we know December is the time of celebration and gifts for our loved ones, we will try and send the goods as soon as possible. Usually the post takes less than a week to deliver, so the expected delivery would be before Christmas. But of course sometimes there are some delays so please be patient! 

Our gifts;

Wooden camera key chain: Walnut body and spruce wood lens. Finish: natural oil and wax. Handmade by Izak Mrgole.

Wooden camera SD card holder: Walnut root and olive wood for the body, spruce wood lens and walnut root for the details. Finish: natural oil and wax. Closes with the help of 2 powerful magnets. Handmade by Izak Mrgole.

007 Camera Robber T-Shirt: 100% cotton quality T-shirt. Designed by Lais Morimoto Lah and hand printed by Jaka Horvat. 

More about the team:

Izak Mrgole - Ilona's older brother; woodworking artist and designer. - The creator of the wooden camera key chain and SD card holder. You can check out more of his other work here: http://www.customguitars.eu , http://www.facebook.com/MagicAtticArt/

Lais Morimoto Lah - A very good friend; painting, drawing and creating all kinds of art. - The person behind the design on the T-Shirt. You can check out more of her other work here: http://www.instagram.com/mandalahart/

Jaka Horvat - Friend; musician, graphic and printing designer. - The one behind the printing on the T-Shirts. Currently does not have a page for his business and but you can check out his personal profile here: https://www.instagram.com/pingoch/

Ezav Mrgole - Ilona's younger brother; promotional and extreme sports video maker. - The author of the video clips. You can check out more of his work here: https://vimeo.com/ezavmrgole

Helena Livia Juvančič - Long time friend, almost part of the family. - Technical support.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot support us with money, please consider to share this campaign with your family, your friends, on social medias and around you!

Remember you can use the Indiegogo Sharing Tools!

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this!
story_txt:
This is a story about Ilona

(Ilona)
Ilona is a 23 year-old student from Slovenia. She travelled from her small hometown of Kamnik to a far away city of Rotterdam in Netherlands. All for following her dream of becoming a professional photographer. 
It was hard in the beginning, being far away from her family and friends, far away from the beautiful nature of Slovenia, in a country that speaks a language that she couldn't understand. But I guess every beginning is hard. 
She successfully finished the 1st year at the Academy of Willem de Kooning.  Studying made Ilona super happy as she noticed that her skills and understanding of Photography were improving a lot trough the year. It gave her so much motivation and during her summer vacation Ilona was working very hard, without any free days, saving up all the money to buy herself a new, better camera.

(Ilona's photo - You can check more of her work here:  https://www.facebook.com/eyeloneah/ , https://eyeloneah.com/ )
After going back to school she decided to sell her old camera together with all the equipment  that she had and combined with her savings it would be just enough to buy a better one. She posted an add on a online page and soon she got a call from a stranger, saying that he want's to buy all the  equipment. The stranger came to visit Ilona at her apartment and asked her all about the camera, equipment and even for advice on how to take better pictures. After some tea and all these questions the stranger made her the transfer (of 1500€) to her account via mobile phone. Ilona, being a little bit naive, but mostly just trustful gave him all the  equipment and he left. But she never got the money on her account...

(Ilona's photo - You can check more of her work here:  https://www.facebook.com/eyeloneah/ , https://eyeloneah.com/ )
So this very much uncompassionate act left young Ilona studying photography in Netherlands without a camera and without the resources to buy a new one.
After hearing her story we were all very angry but mostly just sad, not being able to comprehend the fact how anyone would do such a thing to a young student, without a job, at the beginning of her path.
As we really wanted to help her, but not being able to give her any money, we were all trying to find another way. The idea that came to mind was; why not invest our time and skills into a project that would help us raise some money from kind-hearted people all over the world.
And project Ilona was born :)


What We Need & What You Get
Our basic goal is 1500 € (1700$), which was the amount Ilona was supposed to get by selling her equipment. This is the minimum amount she would need to buy a camera, that would be more appropriate for her skill level, than the one she had before.
Of course any amount is still very helpful, so no matter how much we raise, it all goes into the camera fund! :) 
Because we are really thankful for any support that we get, everyone who donates can choose to receive a unique, handmade gift which we will pack and send to you by post.
How it works;
We created a few products into which we put a lot of time and love. When you donate a certain amount you can choose to receive a small gift as a token of our gratitude. All these gifts are handmade in Slovenia.
If you donate:
*Any amount, you get:  1x certificate for being an awesome person (.PDF)
*12$, you get:   1x handmade wooden camera key chain
*22$, you get:   1x hand printed T-shirt
*45$ you get:   1x handmade wooden camera SD card holder                                     
Of course you can choose to donate without taking the gifts. :)
This project is running until 15th of December. After the project finishes, we will pack and send you the goods to the address that you give us. As we know December is the time of celebration and gifts for our loved ones, we will try and send the goods as soon as possible. Usually the post takes less than a week to deliver, so the expected delivery would be before Christmas. But of course sometimes there are some delays so please be patient! 
Our gifts;

Wooden camera key chain: Walnut body and spruce wood lens. Finish: natural oil and wax. Handmade by Izak Mrgole.

Wooden camera SD card holder: Walnut root and olive wood for the body, spruce wood lens and walnut root for the details. Finish: natural oil and wax. Closes with the help of 2 powerful magnets. Handmade by Izak Mrgole.


007 Camera Robber T-Shirt: 100% cotton quality T-shirt. Designed by Lais Morimoto Lah and hand printed by Jaka Horvat. 
More about the team:

Izak Mrgole - Ilona's older brother; woodworking artist and designer. - The creator of the wooden camera key chain and SD card holder. You can check out more of his other work here: http://www.customguitars.eu , http://www.facebook.com/MagicAtticArt/

Lais Morimoto Lah - A very good friend; painting, drawing and creating all kinds of art. - The person behind the design on the T-Shirt. You can check out more of her other work here: http://www.instagram.com/mandalahart/

Jaka Horvat - Friend; musician, graphic and printing designer. - The one behind the printing on the T-Shirts. Currently does not have a page for his business and but you can check out his personal profile here: https://www.instagram.com/pingoch/

Ezav Mrgole - Ilona's younger brother; promotional and extreme sports video maker. - The author of the video clips. You can check out more of his work here: https://vimeo.com/ezavmrgole

Helena Livia Juvančič - Long time friend, almost part of the family. - Technical support.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot support us with money, please consider to share this campaign with your family, your friends, on social medias and around you!
Remember you can use the Indiegogo Sharing Tools!
Thank you so much for taking the time to read this!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Spencer Zachary, a videographer/photographer and a student at the University of North Carolina - Chapel Hill. Last semester, I had the chance to go study abroad in the wonderful nation of New Zealand at the University of Otago in Dunedin. While I was there, I immersed myself in some of the most beautiful landscapes in the world. This book is an encapsulation of my time there and my best photos I took there. It consists of over 70 images, both film and digital, and a few stories from my time there.

Why Am I Making This Book?

I've found profound enjoyment over the past few years in actually printing my photos instead of them sitting on a hard drive or on social media. Going to such an amazing place, I knew I wanted to do something different and challenge myself to make something new. The idea of a "zine" or an actual book came to me before I left and the idea stuck with me throughout my time there. This process has taught me about design/layout and also allowed me to collaborate with some of my very talented, creative friends.

What I Need & What You Get

My goal is to sell at least 20 books. That would allow me to provide the cheapest prices for customers from the printing service I'm using.

By preordering, you will receive a hardcover 8" x 10" copy of the book! I will be ordering these from the printer and shipping them myself. My goal is to get these shipped before the holiday season of 2019. 

The Impact

A portion of the profits from this project will be donated to the Environmental Defense Fund, a non-profit environmental advocacy group that focuses on issues such as climate change, clean energy, ecosystem restoration and pollution. I got to experience these magnificent places, our grandchildren should be able to see them too.

Thank You!

Thank you so much! I am beyond grateful and hope you enjoy the project. I have loved every step of the way and can't wait to share this book with others.

story:
Short Summary

Hello everyone! As you saw in the video, my name is Shawn Brandow, owner of Brandow Photography. 

I've been a photographer ever since I was old enough to hold a camera, but I've only been in business since 2009. It started when my dad handed me his SLR film camera, a Minolta XD-7, one of the first of it's kind. I began to take photos of everything. Even my friends were susceptible to my paparazzi tendencies!


I loved it. I carried that camera with me everywhere and it became a passion of mine. When I moved to New Mexico in 2006, I bought my first digital camera. This opened a whole new world of possibilities and this only fueled my passion.


I then started Brandow Photography and learned very quickly how competitive this business really is! I have a passion to bring people happiness by capturing their best moments and to show others the beautiful world all around them.

This campaign is to expand my business from being a "just another photographer" business, to "Photographer Extraordinaire!" Business. I have a vision to bring people my high definition art into their homes. Whether the art be of their own family members or a place far away they've never been to. I want to sell my photography as high quality canvas prints and aluminum prints of custom sizes. 

I also want to teach others what I know and to give back to the community. I plan on teaching others the art of photography basics. I will also hold advanced classes for a nominal fee.

By helping me today, you will help me realize my dream and you'll get a piece of that as well, as I'll explain further down.


What I Need & What You Get

This campaign is to raise $25,000 to help me to rent a small studio space and purchase the equipment needed to create even better art and help me to make this a full time career!

  • The average small studio/office space here in Albuquerque runs at about $400-$700 per month. The funding will help to get my doors open and people inside, which will in turn produce more revenue within a couple of months.
  • I will need to print more of my photography to showcase within said studio. Printing those items from my contact in a professional lab will cost a few thousand alone, with a mix of paper print, stretch canvas prints and aluminum prints. Update: For all prints on different mediums, it will cost approximately $4,800.
  • Better Photography equipment is needed to add to my currently outdated equipment, to bring even higher quality photography to my clients: 
  1. Canon 5D Mark III camera with 24-70mm f/4L lens from B&H ($4,149.00)
  2. Battery Grip for camera ($295.95)
  3. 2 Battery Packs ($120)
  4. Canon - EF 200mm f/2.8L II USM Lens ($779)
  5. Canon - EF 70-200mm f/2.8L IS II USM Lens ($2299)
  6. Canon - Speedlite 600EX-RT (x3)($1500)
  • Once I can open the studio itself (on or around January 2015), I will need several lighting setups, so here is a rudimentary list:
  1. Various backdrops and stands ($2000)
  2. Einstein™ E640 Flash Unit (x2)($1000)
  3. Light Stands and booms ($3000)
  4. Furniture and other office items ($1000)
And last but not least, advertising to promote my business within my community, which will cost several more thousand. Advertising is key, and I'll need enough of that to build a larger clientele base so they may eventually do the advertising for me by word of mouth. I'm looking into a radio spot, local and online advertising costs, including banners at local businesses -- such as at the mall, etc.

But what do I get?  I'm glad you asked! As you'll see in the Perks section, depending on how much you contribute to my campaign, you will get high quality prints in varying sizes and materials. The higher the contribution, the larger and better material art you will receive. And what's better? Completely free shipping on all Perk items. AND you get to PICK the art from my gallery. 

Now, I understand that not all campaigns are successful and reach their goal amount. If that is the case with this campaign, that would be unfortunate, but I would still use the money towards expanding my business and you will still get your perks!
The Impact

My main goal is to give back to the community. My gallery and studio will also hold free basic photography classes, with premium advanced classes that can also be accessed online. I want to create an open environment that people will feel welcome to, and not just another photographer's studio that they may feel obligated to purchase items or services. 

Also, successfully funding this campaign would have a major impact on my and my family's lives. To be completely honest, due to the economy we are living paycheck to paycheck at the moment, and expanding this business will help us to get out of that loop. It will ensure that we can do fun things again, like taking our son to the zoo more often or taking mini vacations. Ensuring that we can send him to nice schools down the road. Allowing us to consider having a second child, as we refuse to live off of government assistance. 


By funding this campaign, you not only help enrich our lives, but yours and those around you as well. By receiving one of the great perks to hang on your wall, you expand the vision of everyone that looks at it. The art that is photography can boost morale and entice a sense of wanderlust and happiness. That is what you get, a sense of accomplishment, and that is the greatest feeling of all.

As contributions come in, I will continue to post updates here, showing the progress I am making, thanks to you!

Risks & Challenges

One of the largest challenges I face is reception from the rest of my family, who do not believe photography is a smart business move. Not only do I wish to improve the life of my wife and son, but to prove them wrong! I will be successful.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute monetarily, you can still help me out by using the share button on this page! One of your friends or family members can still help me and I will be greatly appreciated!

story:
Short Summary

We are the 2014 graduating senior photography class finishing our undergraduate degrees in Hartford.
We are raising money for our senior thesis exhibition.
With the donations contributed each student will be able to professionally frame their art work and have a well organized and thought out exhibition. 

What We Need & What You Get

The money that we receive will be divided equally between the twelve graduating seniors. This money will go towards framing the work, providing food and beverages at the show opening and other expenses regarding the exhibition that may arise.

Each student has a very unique and different photographic project.
Some of us use a digital medium while other prefer film and silver printing. We even have a student working with the experimental process in photography called cyanotype. Our projects range from documentary to conceptual photography.

By donating to this cause, you will receive prints and a personalized thank you note from the students who are participating in the show. The more money you donate, the more prints you will receive.

The Impact

This show is incredibly important to us, as it celebrates the four years of hard work and dedication. It is a place where we can display our photographic projects that we have been working on for the past year or more.

Even if our total is not raised, the money will still help us with the expenses of the show and opening reception.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us by spreading the word any way you can.
Send this to friends and family, post on social media sites. anything will help!

Thank you for your support.

story:
The idea

The Angry bat limited edition photobooks is ready to publish it's second publication with the title Morning sun. After last year’s success with the book America, my way, which is now sold out and has also been voted as one of the most interesting photobooks by Douglas Stockdale, now comes a sensual story about the expectation of the first child and an homage to the woman bearing it.

My name is Matej Sitar and I am a photographer and publisher from Slovenia. With the publishing trademark The angry bat I have fulfilled my wish to produce high quality photobooks on my own terms.

"What does it mean to become a father for the first time? How will everything change, what will the days look like and what will be the new routine? Well, I can’t tell the answers to any of those questions, at least not now anyhow.

The intriguing part before going through all of this is the relationship with the partner. The appreciation of her, every point of her body that is constantly changing, but also staying the same. Something familiar that is developing. There is also the fear of the unknown.
I like the changes. I like the look and the feel of it. And the constant reminder that it is her who is important.

Maja, my love."

The text above derived from my thoughts at the moment of the start of this photographic journey and is now, 18 months after it has been written, more true than ever. 

I hope you will help me share this incredible journey with all of you and I am sure you will find joy in it. Whether you are a parent, someone expecting a child or without children, my thought is that you will appreciate the story and the flow of the pictures in this book.

The execution

The good news is that the book is already printed and that there is no risk for you whatsoever. You don't need to be hyped about contributing to the project and then find yourself without a copy because there haven't been enough supporters. Your perk is GUARANTEED. The bad is that there are still a lot of perks waiting for the owner.

Some details about the book:
Dimensions: 21 x 24 cm
Pages: 68 pages
Paper: Fedrigoni Symbol Tatami white 150g
Binding: sewn, hardcover with linen
High quality offset print
Limited Edition of 500 books


I have chosen only the finest materials. High quality voluminous Fedrigoni paper in combination with high quality offset printing to get the most out of the images. Hardback binding with a very nice linen and some beauty details like the embossed title of the book, the tipped in image and a silkscreen text on the spine.
The Special edition is bound in yellow linen with a silkscreen photo on the cover and it comes in a handmade clam shell box, together with a signed and numbered 21x28 cm photo.

The help

If you can, please support my project, that would be awesome.
If you can't make a financial support don't sweat it, every other kind of support is welcomed.
You have a lot of friends on Facebook, LinkedIn, Tweeter, WhatsApp etc.? Yes, perfect! Please share the project with them, maybe a positive word here and there over the internet, the email or maybe just in a conversation will help the project get more attention and would mean the world to me.

Thank you all and take care.

P.S. If you have any questions (or would just like to say hi) don't hesitate to contact me!

The perks

  • Every Euro counts
  • Postcard
  • Early bird book - limited number available
  • 21x28 cm photo
  • Special edition book - limited number available
  • 30x40 cm photo
  • 60x80 cm photo 
  • Photobook workshop in Ljubljana
